dataset.title: Parramore Island of the Virginia Coast Reserve Permanent Plot Resurvey: Shrub data 1996

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Environmental Sciences, Clark Hall, University of Virginia

metadataProvider.organizationName: Virginia Coast Reserve Long-Term Ecological Research Project

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Environmental Sciences, University of Virginia, 291 McCormick Road, PO Box 400123

abstract.para: This dataset includes both the original 1993 and the resurveyed 1996 data. It includes a number of corrections to the original data, and as such it SUPPLANTS and should be used in place of the older "VCR97012 : Shrub Data" dataset.

section.title: Data License
section.para: Data and documentation is copyrighted by The Virginia Coast Reserve LTER project of the University of Virginia (UVA), and ownership remains with the UVA.
The UVA grants you (hereafter, Licensee) a license to use the data and documentation for academic, and research purposes only, without a fee.
Licensee may make derivative works. However, if Licensee distributes any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation, then Licensee will

listitem.para: notify the VCR/LTER designated contact (typically the investigator who collected the data) regarding its distribution of the derivative work, and
clearly notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the UVA.
acknowledge the support of NSF Grants BSR-8702333-06, DEB-9211772, DEB-9411974, DEB-0080381 and DEB-0621014 in any publications using the data and documentation.
send to the address, above, two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation.

section.para: Any Licensee wishing to make commercial use of the data and documentation should contact the UVA, c/o VCR/LTER, to negotiate an appropriate license for such commercial use. Commercial use includes

listitem.para: integration of all or part of the data and documentation into a product for sale or license by or on behalf of Licensee to third parties, or
distribution of the data or documentation to third parties that need it to utilize a commercial product sold or licensed by or on behalf of Licensee.

para.emphasis: UVA MAKES NO REPRESENTATIONS ABOUT THE SUITABILITY OF THIS DATA AND DOCUMENTATION FOR ANY PURPOSE. IT IS PROVIDED "AS IS" WITHOUT EXPRESS OR IMPLIED WARRANTY. THE UVA SHALL NOT BE LIABLE FOR ANY DAMAGES SUFFERED BY THE USERS OF THIS DATA AND DOCUMENTATION.

section.para: By using or copying this data and documentation, Licensee agrees to abide by the copyright law and all other applicable laws of the U.S. including, but not limited to, export control laws, and the terms of this license. UVA shall have the right to terminate this license immediately by written notice upon Licensee's breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. Licensee may be held legally responsible for any copyright infringement that is caused or encouraged by Licensee's failure to abide by the terms of this license.

para.emphasis: This section contains specific methods for this dataset.

description.para: Those woody species having a typical clumped/clustered distribution of stems sprouting out of a common rootstock with multiple forks and a twisted-sprawling-bushy shape that rarely exceeds 3-5m in height were considered to exhibit a typical "shrub" growth form; namely: Myrica cerifera, Baccharis halmifolia, and Iva frutescens. The azimuth and distance from plot center refer to the approximate center of the shrub clump and/or to the largest stem in the cluster (often the same thing). To qualify for inclusion in the stem mapped dataset, at least one stem in the shrub clump had to reach at least 2.5 cm at DBH (diameter at breast height, 1.37 m), the same cutoff for "tree" growth forms. However, instead of diameter at breast height, the basal diameter (BSD, taken immediately above the root collar) of the largest stem was measured to the nearest 0.1 cm. The maximum height of the shrub clump was estimated to the nearest 0.5m. the same way tree height was measured.

The same condition codes as those for trees (1-8) were used for shrubs except that all live shrubs in good condition were coded as "2" and never as code "1". Again, only shrub clumps with live stems had further measurements done on them. New previously untagged shrub clumps with at least one stem attaining 2.5cm or greater at breast height (1.37m) were tagged and location data recorded. For preexisting tagged clumps, azimuths and distances were only corrected as needed. In cases where the shrub clump was previously tagged and many of the stems were still alive but the previously largest stem had since died, the shrub clump was considered to still be alive but the largest remaining stem's BSD was recorded, the old tag moved and nailed to the new largest stem, and this "moving" noted in the remarks.

In addition to BSD and height, a tally of the number of stems at breast height falling into each of five size classes was made: <3cm, 3-6cm, 6-9cm, 9-12cm, and >12cm. These tallied stems could either originate from the rootstock or fork off of a larger aboveground stem, but minor small mostly lateral branches on larger stems were excluded.
The 1996 condition of each shrub was noted using the following codes:

listitem.para: 2 = live leaning and/or forked shrub in apparently good/healthy condition.
3 = live shrub in poor condition (ex. mostly dead, with broken or bent top, etc.).
4 = dead standing shrub , still upright or leaning with much of its crown intact.
5 = dead standing snag, bole only, still upright or leaning but with a broken off top or otherwise missing its crown.
6 = dead fallen shrub , fallen over from windthrow with a partially uprooted root ball.
7 = dead fallen shrub , fallen over due to a broken bole near the base of the trunk.
8 = missing and presumably dead shrub with no sign of the trunk and/or tag.

description.para: (actual field codes were 1,2,0,3,6,4,5,7 resp. but were reordered during data entry).

para.emphasis: This section contains taxonomy for this dataset.

description.para: Anytime that species-id codes were used to identify the vegetation being measured, these IDs match those from the VCR-LTER's list of SPECID codes (based on the first letter of Genus and next two consonants then first letter of species and next two consonants). If something was only IDed to genus, then XXX was filled in for the last three letters of the species code (ex. SMLXXX for Smilax spp.). For some mixes of species a common-form name was used, such as "grass" for any mix of unidentified combination of upland grass species, "herb" for unknown herbaceous species, or "salthay" for a mix in various proportions of Spartina patens and Distichilis spicata.
